info.game_comments: (Sarah: And they're off!  Jeopardy!'s at Churchill Downs, next.)

(1, 1).clue: In the early '90s poet Kofi Awoonor was Ghana's ambassador to this

(2, 1).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew at a bar in Louisville)  In 2 days around the Derby, 80,000 of these are served, requiring 60 tons of crushed ice

(3, 1).clue: In 1867 Charles Weller created the phrase "Now is the time for all good men to come to the aid of the party" to test this

(5, 1).clue: Pass the poi!  It's Hawaiian for "feast"

(6, 1).clue: Franz Gruber wrote the music & Joseph Mohr the lyrics to this Christmas carol

(1, 2).clue: (Hi, I'm Jeff Probst)  Found mainly in Africa, this fastest land mammal is not prospering

(2, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew at the Kentucky Derby Museum in Louisville)  On May 10, 1919, Sir Barton won the Kentucky Derby; a month & a day later, he became the first winner of this

(3, 2).clue: On March 1, 1867 it was admitted to the Union as the 37th state with Omaha as its capital

(5, 2).clue: This drink is used in the traditional Japanese ceremony of Chanoyu

(6, 2).clue: A nonexecutive provider of business funds

(1, 3).clue: Millions of active ones of these hidden in the landscape of Angola make it a dangerous place to stroll

(2, 3).clue: The winner is presented with a garland of these

(3, 3).clue: On October 18 ownership of this territory was transferred from Russia to the United States

(5, 3).clue: In 1904 the U.S. government banned this Plains Indian ceremony, also the name of a Utah film festival

(6, 3).clue: Influential 1962 work containing the line "The chemical barrage has been hurled against the fabric of life"

(1, 4).clue: The famous remains known as "Lucy" are in a museum in this capital of Ethiopia

(2, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew at Churchill Downs in Louisville)  The Derby uses American Teletimer to sort out this, like Cavonnier & Grindstone in 1996

(3, 4).clue: In 1867 the first of this author's more than 100 rags-to-riches tales, "Ragged Dick", was published

(5, 4).clue: In the 1920s rabbi Mordecai Kaplan brought this ceremony for 12-year-old girls into the synagogue

(6, 4).clue: In a Nov. 3, 1969 speech, Richard Nixon referred to this large group that usually withholds its opinions

(1, 5).clue: The metro area of this city in South Africa includes over 400 suburbs, including Soweto

(2, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew at the Kentucky Derby Museum in Louisville)  I'm at the Kentucky Derby Museum, with the saddle of this 3-time Derby-winning rider with a "heavenly" first name

(3, 5).clue: Minnesota farmer Oliver Kelley established this organization of American farmers as a social & educational group

(5, 5).clue: This ceremony at which school or college degrees are conferred is from the Latin for "beginning"

(6, 5).clue: Quiet alliterative nickname of the U.S. Navy's submarine fleet

(1, 1).clue: Poet laureate Robert Southey wrote that "Curses are like young chickens, they always come home to" do this

(2, 1).clue: In 2003 Tim McGraw covered this man's "Tiny Dancer" & performed it with him on the American Music Awards

(3, 1).clue: This was Indira Gandhi's maiden name (her father was India's first P.M.)

(4, 1).clue: In 1909 in a 25-HP plane, Louis Bleriot flew over 23 miles to cross this in 37 minutes

(5, 1).clue: Rather than a single disease, it's a general term for lung diseases involving inflammation

(1, 2).clue: In "Eugene Onegin", Pushkin wrote, "Now southward swept the caravan of the wild" these, "a noisy clan"

(2, 2).clue: This group is heard here covering a song written by Stevie Nicks

(3, 2).clue: Last name of the sisters whose 1846 book of poetry, published under male pseudonyms, sold 2 copies

(4, 2).clue: In 2001 NASA's Helios, a plane powered by this, flew to a record altitude of 96,500 feet

(5, 2).clue: This extinct flying reptile's name is from the Greek for "finger wing"

(1, 3).clue: Pistol calls his wife "my duck" as he kisses her & goes off to war in France in this Shakespeare history play

(2, 3).clue: For "Common Thread", a tribute album to this group, Clint Black contributed "Desperado"

(3, 3).clue: After the death of his younger brother George, he supplied lyrics to Kurt Weill & Jerome Kern

(4, 3).clue: In 1943 Jacqueline Cochran took charge of the Air Force program known by this insect acronym

(5, 3).clue: It's any type of severe mental illness characterized by hallucinations & delusions

(1, 4).clue: "We will eat our mullets, soused in wines" & "sup pheasants' eggs", this Elizabethan dramatist wrote in "The Alchemist"

(2, 4).clue: If you need a friend, Buck Owens was sailing right behind in his hit cover of this Simon & Garfunkel song

(3, 4).clue: On March 17, 1905 Theodore Roosevelt walked this niece, who was marrying her cousin, down the aisle

(4, 4).clue: The Kremer Prize was awarded to Paul MacCready in 1977 for the first plane successfully powered by this

(5, 4).clue: In the 2nd century B.C., this Egyptian astronomer thought that stars were fixed points of light in a rotating sphere

(1, 5).clue: Last name of William Carlos, who wrote, "So much depends upon a red wheel barrow beside the white chickens"

(2, 5).clue: (Hi, I'm Ricky Skaggs) On my 1995 "Solid Ground" album, I covered this famous story song by Harry Chapin

(3, 5).clue: In 1551 this explorer's son Sebastian founded the Merchant Adventurers of London

(4, 5).clue: Company name on the record-setting XP-59 & the JetRanger III helicopter

(5, 5).clue: This subatomic particle, which has no electric charge, consists of a quark & an antiquark

(0, 0).clue: The opening credits of this 2003 action movie are depicted in Braille
